column4: Can someone help me, my nvidia drivers appear to be installed correctly, but when i run "glxinfo | grep direct" i get "direct rendering: No"
how do you know they are installed correctly?
when you boot, or when gdm starts?
don't know what the BUMPS utility is, but you can easily verify that you are using the nvidia drivers or not. First, type this grep nvidia /etc/X11/xorg.conf
you should get one line - Driver  "nvidia"
okay, no problem. Are you using anything like XGL?
okay, what do you get with this glxinfo | grep vendor
I think you are running the xserver-xgl version, not the plain version -- which is why your server vendor is sgi and client is nvidia (which is what I get on my xgl desktop)

okay let me try to explain it. When you install compiz, you actually change the x server that you are running -- which I think kills direct rendering. If you revert back to the 'normal' x server, you will get direct rendering.
yes, but I think there is a way to get direct rendering running with the xgl server -- atleast I read something to that effect. Try searching the gentoo-wiki
there is a script floating around on compiz.net that turns it on and off via a click.
can you give me an example oh how its used?
well, first you have to make sure ssh is running on the remote machine.
then, from your local terminal, ssh username@remotemachine (remotemachine can be the dns name, or ip address -- username is an account on the remote machine)
it is, its for school, ive connected on windows with putty, i just didnt know how in ubuntu
in ubuntu, just open a terminal. Then type ssh username@machinename
thanks but it appears the server is down anyway =/
